questions.text: When one focus is on the retina, and the other is in front of the retina, the type of astigmatism is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Simple Myopia Simple myopia Simple or developmental myopia is the commonest variety. It is considered a physiological error not associated with any eye disease. It commonly occurs at school-going age,e., between 8 years to 12 years, which is also called school myopia.

Highyeild:

Clinical features Symptoms Poor vision for distance (shortsightedness) is the main symptom of myopia. Asthenopic symptoms may occur in patients with a small degree of myopia. Half-shutting of the eyes may be complained about by the child's parents.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:-

Extraedge:

Signs Prominent eyeballs. The anterior chamber is slightly deeper. Pupils are somewhat large and a bit sluggishly reacting. Fundus is normal; a temporal myopic crescent may rarely be seen. In simple myopia, usually, the error is low to moderate that usually does not exceed –6D

questions.text: Cause of decreased vision due to defect is shown in visual:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Astigmatism A pterygium is an elevated, superficial, external ocular mass that usually forms over the perilimbal conjunctiva and extends onto the corneal surface. Pterygia can develop on the nasal and temporal limbus and affect either or both eyes. Pterygia can vary from small, atrophic quiescent lesions to large, aggressive, rapidly growing fibrovascular lesions that can distort the corneal topography. In advanced cases, they can obscure the optical centre of the cornea.

Highyeild:

The pathophysiology of pterygium is characterised by elastotic degeneration of collagen and fibrovascular proliferation, with an overlying epithelium covering.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Presbyopia - Presbyopia is the gradual loss of your eye's ability to focus on nearby objects. It's a natural, often annoying part of aging. Presbyopia usually becomes noticeable in your early to mid-40s and worsens until age 65. Option B Obstruction of visual axis - Option D. Cataract -

Extraedge:

Histopathology of the abnormal collagen in the area of elastotic degeneration shows basophilia with hematoxylin and eosin stains . This tissue also stains with elastic tissue stains, but it is not true elastic tissue in that Elastase does not digest it

questions.text: Scleral Expansion Bands are used in the management of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presbyopia The scleral expansion band procedure reverses presbyopia and increases the baseline tension of the ciliary muscle, which increases the trabecular meshwork pore size. Increasing the pore size makes the scleral expansion band procedure a new therapeutic and preventive modality for ocular hypertension and POAG.

Highyeild:

Caution should be used . This procedure is an investigational device and, as such, is limited by US law to investigational use.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Myopia Option: B. Astigmatism Option: D. Keratoconus

questions.text: IOL power was calculated to be +21.50D for a patient planned for cataract surgery with PC-IOL implantation. Due to unforeseen circumstances, an IOL of +20.00D was placed in the capsular bag. The resultant refractive status of the patient is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypermetropia Here the placement of a plus lens of a lesser number makes the Image formation behind the retina, causing hypermetropia Hypermetropia (hyperopia) or longsightedness i s the refractive state of the eye wherein parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina with the accommodation being at rest. Clinical features Symptoms: Asymptomatic. Asymptomatic Asthenopic symptoms. Defective vision with asthenopic symptoms. Defective vision only. The effect of ageing on vision ageing is that due to a decrease in accommodative power, the hypermetropia becomes manifest. To begin with, blurring occurs for near vision and then for distant vision.

Highyeild:

Signs The size of the eyeball may appear small Cornea appears smaller The anterior chamber is shallow. Retinoscopy and auto refractometry reveal hypermetropic refractive error. Fundus examination reveals a small optic disc that may look more vascular with ill-defined margins and may simulate papillitis (though there is no disc swelling, so it is called pseudo papillitis). The retina may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections (shot silk appearance). A-scan ultrasonography (biometry) reveals a short anteroposterior eyeball length in axial hypermetropia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Myopia Option: C. Astigmatism Option: D. Presbyopia

Extraedge:

Grading of hypermetropia Low hypermetropia , when the error is < + 2D. Moderate hypermetropia , when the error is between +2 to + 5D. High hypermetropia when the error is > + 5D.

questions.text: Regular astigmatism means which of the following?
questions.correct_answer: A. The two meridians are perpendicular
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The two meridians are perpendicular Principal meridians at 90° to each other regular astigmatism° Principal meridians at 90° to each other but don't tie at or near 90° or 180° oblique astigmatism. Astigmatism is a condition of refraction in which a point of focus of light. cannot be formed upon the retina. The optical condition is that instead of a a single focal point, there are two or more focal lines (depending on the type of astigmatism), separated from each other by a focal interval.

Highyeild:

Etiological classification: Curvature astigmatism : Most commonly , it is corneal, where vertical curvature is more than horizontal curvature (due to the pressure of the upper eyelid), less commonly, it is lenticular (induced by lens). Decentering astigmatism : subluxation of lens. Index astigmatism : due to cataract in one meridian.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B .Compound astigmatism : neither of the two foci lies upon the retina but are both placed in front or behind the retina (myopic or hypermetropic, respectively). Option: C . Mixed astigmatism : one focus in front and the other behind the Option: D. Irregular astigmatism : refraction in different meridians is quite irregular. Found in the pathological condition of the cornea, irregular healing after trauma, inflammations, or keratoconus.

Extraedge:

Clinical classification: Regular : two principal meridians at the right angle are involved (i.e. there is the difference in the refractive power of two meridians 90° in between): a- Simple astigmatism : myopic or hypermetropic; one of the foci falls on retina, other in front or behind it.

questions.text: Which type of refractive error is seen in keratoconus-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Irregular Astigmatism Because of irregular corneal surface and conical cornea , irregular astigmatism usually occurs. Irregular astigmatism : refraction in different meridians is quite irregular. Found in pathological condition of the cornea; irregular healing after trauma or inflammations or keratoconus.

Highyeild:

Astigmatism is a condition of refraction in which a point of focus of light. cannot be formed upon the retina. The optical condition is that instead of a a single focal point, there are two or more focal lines (depending on the type of astigmatism), separated from each other by a focal interval.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Regular: two principal meridians at a right angle are involved (i.e. there is the difference in the refractive power of two meridians 90° in between): a- Simple astigmatism : myopic or hypermetropic; one of the foci falls on retina, other in front or behind it. b- Compound astigmatism : neither of the two foci lies upon the retina but are both placed in front or behind the retina (myopic or hypermetropic, respectively). c- Mixed astigmatism : one focus in front and the other behind the retina Option C. Myopia Option D. Hypermetropia

questions.text: A 10-year-old complains of a headache. His best corrected visual acuity in the right eye is 6/36, and in the left is 6/6. Retinoscopy shows +5D in the right eye and +1D in the left eye. All other ocular examinations are normal. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amblyopia Vision in the right eye is 6/36, but the ocular examination is Thus there is no organic cause for decreased vision (Anisometropic amblyopia due to >2.5D difference in refractory power between the two eyes).

Highyeild:

Types of Amblyopia ;- Congenital amblyopia :- Since birth, one is not using vision Acquired amblyopia The ametropic amblyopia :-one eye is highly ametropic, having less vision which forms a blurred image, so the brain suppresses it, causing amblyopia. Strabismic amblyopia :-image formed by the eye with a squint in place other than the fovea so the brain suppresses it causing amblyopia Anisometropic amblyopia : if the difference is high, the eye with high refractive error is suppressed. Stimulation deprivation amblyopia : amblyopia due to not using an eye for vision.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Optic neuritis , Option: B. Cortical blindness Option: D. Malingering

Extraedge:

What is Malingering? French malingerer- 'to suffer' or 'pretend to be ill' "Malingering is intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychologic symptoms motivated by external incentives" - DSM-5

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has 6/5 vision, each eye unaided. His cycloplegic retinoscopy is +0.1D sph. at 1 meter distance. His complaints are blurring of newsprint at 30 cm, which clears up in about 2 minutes, The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Accommodative inertia The accommodative system is slow in making a change and represents a loss of accommodative inertia . Accommodative inertia refers to the delay in response to accommodation .

Highyeild:

Normally an accommodative change occurs in 1 sec.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Hypermetropia will not resolve. Option b-Presbyopia usually occurs at around 40 due to physiological insufficiency of accommodation and can not clear in 2 minutes. Option: B. Presbyopia Option: D .Cycloplegia leading accommodation, will resolve in hours to a day depending upon the drug used (10-20 days after atropine)

Extraedge:

What is Cycloplegia? It is the paralysis of the ciliary muscle of the eye, resulting in the loss of visual accommodation. Accommodation is the ability of the lens to change its refractive power to view the near objects clearly. It is brought about by the contraction of the ciliary muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following is the true statement about accommodation:

options.label: A
options.text: Mainly occur due to change in curvature of the posterior surface of the lens

options.label: D
options.text: Produced due to an increase in curvature of the anterior surface of the lens.

questions.correct_answer: D. Produced due to an increase in curvature of the anterior surface of the lens.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Produced due to an increase in curvature of the anterior surface of the lens. The amplitude of accommodation : Dioptric power difference between rest and fully accommodated eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . A-P-R (A: amplitude of accommodation; P: the dioptric value of the near point; and R: the dioptric value of the far point.) Accommodative Convergence/Accommodation Ratio Option: B . To view near objects: Accommodation for clear retinal images & Convergence for binocular single vision. -The number of prism dioptres of convergence that accompanies each dioptre of accommodation is (AC/A) ratio Option: C .The normal range for the AC/A ratio is 3:1 to 5:1.

questions.text: All are true about presbyopia except:

options.label: A
options.text: Common in the young age group

options.label: B
options.text: Not able to see near objects

options.label: C
options.text: Spectacles having unifocal or bifocal lenses should be used

options.label: D
options.text: Correction of refractive error should be done

questions.correct_answer: A. Common in the young age group
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Common in the young age group Presbyopia is common in older age groups.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Not being able to see near objects is a true statement regarding presbyopia. Option: C . Spectacles having a unifocal or bifocal lens should be used - yes, this is correct. Option: D . Correction of refractive error should be done - yes, this is needed while dealing with presbyopia.

questions.text: The following given image is indicative of which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Accommodative Esotropia Accommodative esotropia- occurs due to the overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint in children (previously, it was believed that congenital esotropia was most common). When esotropia develops around 2-3 years of age, it is most likely accommodative.

Highyeild:

It is of three types: refractive. non-refractive and mixed. i. Refractive accommodative esotropia : It usually develops at the age of 2 to 3 years and is associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D). Mostly it is for near and distance (marginally more for near) and fully correctable by use of spectacles ii. Non-refractive accommodative esotropia : It is caused by an abnormal AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio. This may occur even in patients with no refractive error. Esotropia is greater for near than that for distance (minimal or no deviation for distance). It is fully corrected by bifocal glasses with add +3 DS for near vision. Miotics may be useful in younger children not suitable for bifocals. Miotics facilitate accommodation and thus reduce the accommodative convergence. iii. Mixed accommodative esotropia : It is caused by a combination of hypermetropia and a high AC/A ratio . Esotropia for distance is corrected by correction of hypermetropia; and the residual esotropia for near is corrected by an addition of a +3 DS lens.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Consecutive esotropia Consecutive esotropias refer to a convergent strabismus that has developed following surgery for an exotropia. This is relatively rare but can happen following surgery for an intermittent distance exotropia Option: C. Infantile esotropia Infantile esotropia is a form of ocular motility disorder in which there is an inward turning of one or both eyes, commonly referred to as "crossed eyes". Infantile esotropia is esotropia that occurs during the first 6 months of life in an otherwise neurologically normal child. Option: D. Sensory esotropia Sensory exotropia is a condition of unilateral divergence as a sequela to loss of vision or long-standing poor vision in one eye, caused by refractive errors, unilateral aphakia or other organic reasons.

Extraedge:

Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: conv359ex glasses Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens. The algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows: R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics

questions.text: Shamita brought her 6-year-old son to OPD, and he was found to have a recent onset of 15-degree esotropia. Which of the following is the best line of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reliving prism The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction. The treatment of hypermetropia corrects esotropia for distance : conv359ex glasses Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens. The algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows: R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics

Highyeild:

It is of three types: refractive. non-refractive and mixed. Refractive accommodative esotropia usually develops at 2 to 3 years old and is associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D). Mostly it is for near and distance (marginally more for near) and fully correctable by spectacles Non-refractive accommodative esotropia is caused by an abnormal AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio. This may occur even in patients with no refractive error. Esotropia is greater for near than that distance (minimal or no deviation for distance). It is fully corrected by bifocal glasses with add +3 DS for near vision. Miotics may be helpful in younger children not suitable for bifocals. Miotics facilitate accommodation and thus reduce the accommodative convergence. Mixed accommodative esotropia is caused by a combination of hypermetropia and a high AC/A ratio . Esotropia for distance is corrected by correction of hypermetropia, and the residual esotropia for near is corrected by adding a +3 DS lens.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A .Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia Option: B . Operative correction: for non-accommodative component Option: C .Prism correction: for remaining error

questions.text: Suresh, a 7 years old boy, came to OPD with crossed eyes and was examined by an ophthalmologist. He was diagnosed with left esotropia and amblyopia in the left eye. By what age should amblyopia be corrected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

8 years Strabismic amblyopia should be corrected before 8 years of age. The sensitive period during which the acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved is usually up to 7-8 years in strabismic amblyopia and maybe longer (into the teens) for anisometropic amblyopia when a good binocular function is present.

Highyeild:

Treatment of amblyopia: 1. Occlusion of the normal eye , to encourage the use of the amblyopic eye, is the most effective treatment. 2. Penalization , in which vision in the normal eye is blurred with atropine, is an alternative method.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . This is not the correct option Option: C . This is not the correct option. Option D . This is not the correct option.

Extraedge:

In the absence of an organic lesion , a difference in best-corrected visual acuity (VA) of two Snellen lines or more (or >1 log unit) is indicative of amblyopia.
